docs.lead_paragraph: New monkey studies show that one shot of an experimental Ebola vaccine can trigger fast protection, but the effect waned unless the animals got a booster shot made a different way.

headline.main: Monkey Study: Ebola Vaccine Works, Needs Booster
headline.print_headline: Monkey Study: Ebola Vaccine Works, Needs Booster

docs.snippet: New monkey studies show that one shot of an experimental Ebola vaccine can trigger fast protection, but the effect waned unless the animals got a booster shot made a different way.

docs.lead_paragraph: New books by Terrence Holt, Judy Melinek and T. J. Mitchell, and Paul A. Marks and James Sterngold.
docs.abstract: Danielle Ofri reviews books Internal Medicine: A Doctor's Stories by Terrence Holt, Working Stiff: Two Years, 262 Bodies and the Making of a Medical Examiner by Judy Melinek and T J Mitchell and On the Cancer Frontier: One Man, One Disease, and a Medical Revolution by Paul A Marks and James Sterngold.
docs.snippet: New books by Terrence Holt, Judy Melinek and T. J. Mitchell, and Paul A. Marks and James Sterngold.

docs.lead_paragraph: As West Africa struggles to contain the biggest ever outbreak of Ebola, some experts say an unusual but simple treatment might help: the blood of survivors.

headline.main: Could the Blood of Ebola Survivors Help Patients?
headline.print_headline: Could the Blood of Ebola Survivors Help Patients?

docs.snippet: As West Africa struggles to contain the biggest ever outbreak of Ebola, some experts say an unusual but simple treatment might help: the blood of survivors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the World Health Organization, described how the agency offered assistance in the Ebola crisis.

headline.main: W.H.O. Leader Describes the Agency’s Ebola Operations

docs.lead_paragraph: The hospital in Liberia where three American aid workers got sick with Ebola has been overwhelmed by a surge in patients and doesn't have enough hazard suits and other supplies to keep doctors and nurses safe, a missionary couple told The Associated Press on Wednesday.

headline.main: Ebola Survivors: Hospital Staff Exposed in Africa
headline.print_headline: Ebola Survivors: Hospital Staff Exposed in Africa

docs.snippet: The hospital in Liberia where three American aid workers got sick with Ebola has been overwhelmed by a surge in patients and doesn't have enough hazard suits and other supplies to keep doctors and nurses safe, a missionary couple told The Associated...

docs.lead_paragraph: If it goes the way of the West, its gains in life span may be eroded.
docs.abstract: Mark Bittman Op-Ed column considers whether China can pull off public-health leapfrog and avoid the West's fate of rapid and tragic increase in obesity levels and accompanying diseases; highlights research in journal The Lancet that shows dangers of obesity, including its links to diabetes and cancer; laments that America may need China's example to address its own problems with obesity.
docs.snippet: If it goes the way of the West, its gains in life span may be eroded.

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans' eating habits have improved — except among the poor, evidence of a widening wealth gap when it comes to diet. Yet even among wealthier adults, food choices remain far from ideal, a 12-year study found.

headline.main: US Eating Habits Improve a Bit _ Except Among Poor
headline.print_headline: US Eating Habits Improve a Bit _ Except Among Poor

docs.snippet: Americans' eating habits have improved — except among the poor, evidence of a widening wealth gap when it comes to diet. Yet even among wealthier adults, food choices remain far from ideal, a 12-year study found.
